title: Leni Apisai
text:
Leni Chris Anitoni Apisai (born 8 March 1996) is a New Zealand <a href="Rugby%20Union">rugby union</a> player who currently plays as a <a href="Hooker%20%28rugby%20union%29">hooker</a> for in New Zealand's domestic <a href="Mitre%2010%20Cup">Mitre 10 Cup</a> and the in the international <a href="Super%20Rugby">Super Rugby</a> competition.
Early career.
Born in the town of <a href="Porirua">Porirua</a> in the greater <a href="Wellington">Wellington</a> metropolitan area, Apisai was educated at <a href="Aotea%20College">Aotea College</a> in his hometown before later moving to <a href="Wellington%20College%20%28New%20Zealand%29">Wellington College</a> where he played first XV rugby. During his high school years, he turned out for at age group level and captained their under-16 side.
Senior Rugby.
Aged just 18, Apisai first played provincial rugby for during the <a href="2014%20ITM%20Cup">2014 ITM Cup</a>, making 2 appearances including 1 start. The campaign was not a happy one for the Lions as they were relegated down to the Championship division for the <a href="2015%20ITM%20Cup">2015 season</a> after recording just 1 win in 10 games.
Wellington were unable to gain promotion back to the Premiership at the first time of asking, finishing 2nd behind on the Championship log before being defeated 26-25 by the same opposition in the playoff final. Although the season was one of disappointment for his team, for Apisai personally, it saw him take advantage of <a href="Motu%20Matu%27u">Motu Matu'u</a>'s involvement with in the <a href="2015%20Rugby%20World%20Cup">2015 Rugby World Cup</a> to establish himself as the Lions first choice in the number 2 jersey, playing all 12 games during the season and scoring 2 tries.
Matu'u departed for <a href="Gloucester%20Rugby">Gloucester</a> prior to the <a href="2016%20Mitre%2010%20Cup">2016 Mitre 10 Cup</a> leaving Apisai unchallenged as Wellington's main hooker for the year. He played 10 of their 11 games during the year and helped himself to 3 tries as they once again finished 2nd in the Championship, this time behind and were then surprisingly defeated 40-37 at home by in the playoff semi-finals with his 11th minute try scored in vain.
Super Rugby.
After just 2 provincial appearances for Wellington, Apisai was named as part of the wider training group ahead of the <a href="2015%20Super%20Rugby%20season">2015 Super Rugby season</a>. Unsurprisingly given his tender years and lack of top-level experience, he was unable to get on the field at any point during the year, taking the role of the franchise's fourth choice rake behind; <a href="Dane%20Coles">Dane Coles</a>, Motu Matu'u and <a href="Brayden%20Mitchell">Brayden Mitchell</a>.
Doors began to open for him ahead of the <a href="2016%20Super%20Rugby%20season">2016 season</a> with Mitchell leaving after his short-term contract had expired and Coles and Matu'u both being struck down by injury in pre-season. Apisai was left temporarily as the 'Canes first choice number 2 and debuted in week 1 of the season, a 52-10 defeat away to the . This heavy defeat was in stark contrast to what followed throughout the rest of the year as the 'Canes bounced back to lift the Super Rugby title in August with a 20-3 win over the . Apisai started the first 3 games of the year and played a total of 5 matches in his first season as a member of the franchise's senior squad.
Apisai signed to the Blues for the 2018 Super Rugby season.
International.
Apisai was a <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20schoolboy%20rugby%20union%20team">New Zealand Schools</a> representative in 2013 and was later captained the <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">New Zealand Under-20</a> side which finished 5th in the <a href="2016%20World%20Rugby%20Under%2020%20Championship">2016 World Rugby Under 20 Championship</a> in England, scoring 1 try in 5 matches.
In October 2016 Apisai, who affiliates to the <a href="Ng%C4%81ti%20Awa">Ngāti Awa</a> <a href="iwi">iwi</a>, was named in the <a href="M%C4%81ori%20All%20Blacks">Māori All Blacks</a> squad for their <a href="2016%20end-of-year%20rugby%20union%20internationals">end-of-year tour to the Northern Hemisphere</a>. He debuted as a 75th minute replacement for the Māori captain <a href="Ash%20Dixon">Ash Dixon</a> in a 27-14 defeat by <a href="Munster%20Rugby">Munster</a> on 11 November 2016.
